elements.title: Current-Week Hero Card: Invert the Stays Table so Today's Answer Comes First
elements.problem: The Stays Manager presents all stays as a flat table with columns for Week #, Period, Status, and Actions. A guest with a 13-week lease sees 13 rows of equal visual weight. To answer the only question that matters on a weekly visit -- 'What do I need to do right now?' -- the guest must visually scan the table, skip past completed weeks, identify the current or next upcoming week, read its status, and determine the appropriate action. This is a System 2 scan task imposed on a page visited every week for 3+ months. Kahneman's research on cognitive ease demonstrates that repeated tasks should become easier with practice, but a table that grows with completed rows becomes harder to scan over time -- the opposite of skill acquisition. The hybrid worker target persona (Bryant at 10:17-12:17: 'Monday to Friday is a very popular usage pattern... 2-3 month commitments typical') checks this page on Monday mornings before heading to the property. Their System 2 is allocated to work responsibilities, not to parsing a data table. Layer 1 (works-003) identified the process problem; this element defines the information hierarchy that solves it.
elements.solution: Structure the Stays Manager page around a single hero card for the current or next actionable stay, with all other information subordinated. The hero card answers the guest's weekly question in a single glance: the week number, the date range, the status, and the one action available (if any). Completed stays collapse into a summary line ('6 stays completed'). Future stays collapse into a count ('6 weeks remaining'). The full table is available as a secondary view for guests who want the complete picture, but it is never the default. The information hierarchy is: (1) current week card, (2) pending alerts (date changes, payments), (3) summary of past and future. This mirrors how a calendar app shows today's events first, not January 1st.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 392-408
evidence.quote: Stays (X) - Individual visit tracking. Stays Table: Columns: Week #, Period (date range), Status (Not Started, In Progress, Completed), Actions. Available Actions: Review, Upload Photos, Report Issue, No action available.
evidence.insight: The current design gives Week 1 (completed two months ago) and Week 13 (three weeks from now) the same visual weight. The guest must scan past irrelevant rows to find the relevant one. 'No action available' appears for all future stays, creating visual noise that dilutes the signal of actionable items.

evidence.quote: Monday to Friday is a very popular usage pattern... typically looking for really weeknights or weekdays each week... 2-3 month commitments typical.
evidence.insight: The primary guest persona visits this page weekly for 2-3 months. Each visit is a micro-interaction: check status, see if anything needs attention, leave. The page must be optimized for this repeated micro-interaction, not for a comprehensive management session.

evidence.quote: As you become skilled in a task, its demand for energy diminishes... A general 'law of least effort' applies to cognitive as well as physical exertion.
evidence.insight: A hero card that always appears in the same position with the same structure becomes a System 1 pattern after 2-3 visits: the guest knows where to look and what to expect. A table that changes row count each week never becomes automatic because the target location shifts downward with each completed stay.

evidence.quote: System 2 also has a natural speed... there is little strain... Just like a stroll. Accelerating beyond my strolling speed completely changes the experience.
evidence.insight: The weekly Stays Manager check should be a cognitive 'stroll.' Scanning a 13-row table to find the current week is a cognitive 'jog' that the guest is forced into every single visit. Over 13 weeks, this unnecessary acceleration accumulates into resentment toward the platform.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: current/next stay hero card (week number, dates, status, single action). Secondary: alert banner for pending date changes, upcoming payments, or host messages. Tertiary: collapsed summary of completed and upcoming stays with expandable detail.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Immediate on page load: hero card with current week status and action. On scroll: alert area for pending items. On tap/expand: full stays table for comprehensive view. The hero card is never hidden, never scrolled past, and never visually subordinated to the table.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: One card, one status, one action on the primary view. Maximum 3 data points above the fold: week number, date range, action button. The full 13-row table is accessible but requires deliberate expansion.
scan_order: Hero card: week number and date range (System 1 recognition: 'This is my week', under 1 second)
Status badge on hero card: In Progress, Completed, or Not Started (System 1 assessment: 'Am I good?', 1-2 seconds)
Action button: Review, Upload Photos, or no action needed (System 1 decision: 'Do I need to do anything?', 2-3 seconds)
Alert area: pending date changes or payment reminders (System 2 engagement only if present, 3-5 seconds)
exclude: Flat table as the default view. The table is a secondary view accessed by deliberate expansion.
Completed stays displayed at the same visual weight as the current stay. Past stays collapse into a one-line summary.
Future stays listed individually with 'No action available.' Future stays are a count, not a list.
Any information that requires the guest to scroll to find the current week.

elements.title: One-Number Financial Legibility: Show the Guest's Cost in Their Mental Format Before Any Breakdown
elements.problem: The guest's financial mental model is monthly budget. The platform speaks in nightly rates. The listing page shows '$300.98/night' as the primary number, with '4-Week Rent: $3,611.79' and 'Reservation Estimated Total: $11,738.32' as secondary figures. The guest must perform mental arithmetic to determine whether this fits their monthly budget -- the exact kind of computation that Kahneman's bat-and-ball research shows over 50% of elite university students get wrong. The Nneka call reveals that even established lease pricing ($1,170-$1,175/month) requires translation between monthly and nightly formats. In the Stays Manager, the Payment Schedule shows individual payment rows ($1,400 + $60 maintenance = $1,460) without a cumulative total or comparison to the guest's expected monthly cost. At every financial touchpoint, the guest must translate, compute, and verify -- three System 2 operations that compound across phases and deplete the cognitive budget needed for actual decisions.
elements.solution: At every financial touchpoint, lead with one number in the guest's native format: the monthly cost. On the listing page, the primary financial display is 'Monthly cost: $3,612' in large type. The nightly rate ('$300.98/night') appears as an explanatory subtitle. On the proposal summary, the primary number is 'Your total commitment: $11,738' followed by 'over 20 weeks (approximately $2,347/month).' In the Stays Manager Payment Schedule, the primary number is 'This period: $1,460' with a running total: 'Paid to date: $4,380 of $11,738.' The guest never performs arithmetic. Every financial screen answers the same question first: 'What does this cost me in terms I already understand?'

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 83-106
evidence.quote: Nightly Rate Display: Large: '$300.98 /night'. Cost Breakdown: '4-Week Rent: $3,611.79'. 'Reservation Estimated Total: $11,738.32'. Primary CTA: 'Create Proposal at $300.98/night'.
evidence.insight: The listing page presents three financial figures simultaneously: nightly rate, 4-week rent, and total. The guest must hold all three in working memory and compute their monthly equivalent. The CTA reinforces the nightly rate as the anchor, but the guest's decision is based on monthly budget. The primary number and the decision-making number are different formats.

evidence.quote: Originally when I... I believe $1,170, $1,175.
evidence.insight: Even established lease pricing is referenced in monthly terms ($1,170-$1,175/month), not nightly terms. Both hosts and guests think in monthly costs. The platform's nightly rate display serves the platform's data model, not the user's mental model.

evidence.quote: More than 50% of students at Harvard, MIT, and Princeton gave the intuitive -- incorrect -- answer. Many people are overconfident, prone to place too much faith in their intuitions.
evidence.insight: If over 50% of elite students fail simple arithmetic under cognitive ease, guests performing nightly-to-monthly conversion while evaluating photos, rules, and location will produce errors at an even higher rate. Wrong mental math leads to either sticker shock at proposal time (when the real monthly cost is computed) or to agreeing to a lease that exceeds their budget.

evidence.quote: Effort is required to maintain simultaneously in memory several ideas that require separate actions, or that need to be combined according to a rule.
evidence.insight: Three financial figures (nightly, 4-week, total) each require a separate mental operation: interpret, convert, compare to budget. Holding three figures while performing three operations exceeds the 4-item working memory threshold. One pre-converted monthly figure requires zero operations.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: one monthly-equivalent cost figure in large type. Secondary: the nightly rate as an explanatory subtitle showing how the monthly figure was derived. Tertiary: the full cost breakdown (4-week rent, total reservation, per-night calculation) available on demand behind an expand control.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Immediate: monthly cost equivalent displayed on page load. On secondary scan: nightly rate shown beneath as derivation context. On demand: full breakdown with line items for guests who want to verify. At proposal creation: single total commitment figure before any itemization. In Payment Schedule: period cost plus running total against overall commitment.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 1 financial figure at primary visual weight. Maximum 2 supporting figures visible without interaction (nightly rate, total). All mental arithmetic is performed by the platform and displayed as pre-computed results. The guest never divides, multiplies, or sums.
scan_order: Monthly cost equivalent: the one number that answers 'Can I afford this?' (System 1 gut check, under 2 seconds)
Nightly rate subtitle: context for how the monthly figure was derived (System 1 to System 2 bridge, 2-4 seconds)
Total commitment figure: answers 'What am I signing up for overall?' (System 2 verification, 4-6 seconds)
Expand control for full breakdown: answers 'Show me the math' (System 2 deep verification, only if needed)
exclude: Nightly rate as the primary financial display. Nightly rate is a platform unit, not a guest decision unit.
Multiple financial figures at equal visual weight. Only one number is primary.
CTA buttons that reference the nightly rate ('Create Proposal at $300.98/night'). The CTA should reference the monthly commitment or the total.
Payment Schedule rows without a running total. Individual period payments are meaningless without cumulative context.

elements.title: Inline Financial Consequence for Every Date Change Option
elements.problem: The Date Change section of the Stays Manager presents three change types (Add nights, Remove nights, Swap dates) and a pricing section that describes rules ('Buying back nights: Host pays guest. Adding nights: Guest pays host. Fair market rate calculation'). But the guest does not need rules; they need numbers. Nneka's call reveals that 'replace' and 'add' have fundamentally different pricing implications -- additions are at a 'different rate' (07:22-07:45) and seasonal pricing means even replacements can cost more (03:33-04:26). The guest's System 1 treats 'change my dates' as a single coherent action. It does not automatically decompose this into three options with three different financial consequences. Kahneman's associative coherence research shows that the mind links related concepts into a single story; the platform must show each option as a distinct story with a distinct financial ending, or the guest will choose based on label alone and be surprised by the cost.
elements.solution: When the guest initiates a date change from a specific stay row, present the available options as a single-screen choice where each option shows its concrete financial consequence for this specific change: (1) 'Swap: Move Oct 15 to Oct 22. Cost difference: +$0' or '+$12 (Oct 22 is in a higher-rate period).' (2) 'Add: Keep Oct 15 and also book Oct 22. Additional cost: $95 (current rate).' (3) 'Remove: Cancel Oct 15. Refund: $80.' Each option is a single visual unit: action label + specific dates + dollar amount. The guest selects the option that matches their intent and budget in one tap. No abstract rules, no policy descriptions, no 'fair market rate calculation' labels that require System 2 translation.

evidence.quote: If Brad was to add a book tonight, and add instead of like replace, is that something that you would be open to and if so, would that be at a different rate... it would be a different rate.
evidence.insight: Even the Split Lease team must explicitly ask whether replace and add have different rates. If the internal team needs clarification, the guest cannot be expected to understand this distinction from labels alone. The financial consequence must be attached to each option, not described in a separate pricing policy section.

evidence.quote: It's not working financially... Originally when I... I believe $1,170, $1,175... the new dates are priced higher now.
evidence.insight: Seasonal pricing means a 'swap' that the guest expects to be cost-neutral can actually cost more. The delta between the original rate and the replacement rate must be visible before the guest commits, not after. Showing '+$0' for a true swap and '+$12' for a seasonal-adjusted swap builds trust through transparency.

evidence.quote: Your System 1 made as much sense as possible of the situation... by linking the words in a causal story; it evaluated the possible threat... and created a context for future developments.
evidence.insight: System 1 creates a story for each option: 'I swap and pay nothing extra' or 'I add and pay $95 more.' If the financial consequence is not part of the story (because it is in a separate pricing section), the guest creates an incomplete story and is surprised when the bill arrives. Attaching the dollar amount to the option label completes the story at the moment of choice.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 419-428
evidence.quote: Change Types: Add nights (guest pays more), Remove nights (guest gets refund), Swap dates. Pricing: Buying back nights: Host pays guest. Adding nights: Guest pays host. Fair market rate calculation.
evidence.insight: The UI separates change types from pricing into two distinct sections. The guest must read the change types, then scroll to the pricing section, then mentally connect the two. This separation forces a cross-referencing task that System 2 handles poorly under depletion. Merging type and price into a single visual unit eliminates the cross-reference.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: each change option as a combined unit of action + specific dates + dollar impact. Secondary: the Flexibility Score shown as context ('Your host has accommodated 4 of 5 requests'), not as a gatekeeper. Tertiary: detailed pricing explanation available on demand for guests who want to understand how the rate was calculated.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Immediate: the three options with dollar amounts, specific to this guest's situation and these specific dates. No abstract rules, no policy references. On selection: confirmation screen showing the selected option, the host notification that will be sent, and expected response time. On demand: detailed pricing breakdown showing original rate, new date rate, seasonal factor, and calculation method.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 3 options visible simultaneously. Each option is one line: action verb + dates + dollar amount. No scrolling required to see all options. No cross-referencing between a 'types' section and a 'pricing' section. The Flexibility Score is a single percentage with a one-line explanation, never a chart or graph.
scan_order: The three change options as a visual group: Swap, Add, Remove (System 1 pattern recognition: 'Which one matches my intent?', under 3 seconds)
Dollar amount attached to each option (System 1 financial assessment: 'What does each cost?', 3-5 seconds)
Specific dates in each option (System 2 verification: 'Are these the right dates?', 5-7 seconds)
Flexibility Score context line (System 2 social consideration: 'Is my host flexible?', 7-9 seconds, only if displayed)
exclude: Abstract pricing rule descriptions ('fair market rate calculation', 'buying back nights'). Show dollars, not rules.
Separate sections for change types and pricing. Type and cost are a single visual unit.
Options that lead to unavailable dates. Only show dates the host has available, pulling from synced calendar data.
Flexibility Score displayed as a barrier or guilt mechanism. It is informational context, not a gate.

elements.title: Pre-Commitment Rate Anchoring: Show Seasonal Variability Before the Guest Locks a Price in Memory
elements.problem: Nneka reveals that her original rate was $1,170-$1,175/month but seasonal pricing means rescheduled dates are more expensive (03:33-04:26). This creates a trust-destroying pattern: the guest commits at one price, then encounters a different price when rescheduling mid-lease. Kahneman's anchoring research demonstrates that the first number a person sees becomes their reference point; deviations from that anchor are experienced as gains or losses relative to it, not as objective market values. The listing page currently shows a single nightly rate ($300.98) and a single 4-week rent ($3,611.79). If the guest's lease spans two pricing seasons, they anchor on the rate shown at listing evaluation and experience any seasonal increase during the active lease as a penalty -- even if the higher rate was disclosed somewhere in the fine print. The information architecture must prevent this anchoring trap by surfacing rate variability before the guest's System 1 locks onto a single number.
elements.solution: At listing evaluation, when the guest's selected dates span a period where rates may change, show the rate range rather than a single rate: 'Your rate: $280-$301/night depending on season. Oct-Dec: $280/night. Jan-Feb: $301/night.' At proposal creation, the cost summary shows the blended rate and flags any seasonal variation: 'Your 20-week reservation spans two rate periods. Weeks 1-12: $280/night. Weeks 13-20: $301/night. Total: $11,738.' At acceptance, the confirmation includes a one-line clause: 'Date changes are priced at the rate for the new dates. See your rate schedule above.' In the Stays Manager, the Payment Schedule labels each period with its applicable rate so the guest can see which rate governs which weeks. The pattern is: never let the guest anchor on a single rate when their lease will encounter multiple rates.

evidence.quote: Originally when I... I believe $1,170, $1,175. And that was... therefore I am not able to do that... the new dates are priced higher now.
evidence.insight: The host cannot honor the original rate for rescheduled dates because seasonal pricing has increased. If the guest was never shown that rates vary by season, they experience the increase as a broken promise rather than a market adjustment. Pre-commitment disclosure transforms a trust violation into an expected and accepted variable.

evidence.quote: By providing him the flexibility, you're not leaving the days available that were booked before... by pushing them back, it's sort of taking days away that were previously available.
evidence.insight: Rescheduling has an opportunity cost (blocked dates cannot be rebooked at higher seasonal rates). The guest who understands why rates differ by season can accept the logic. The guest who anchored on a single rate cannot.

evidence.quote: Now that you have measured the lines, you -- your System 2 -- have a new belief: you know that the lines are equally long. But you still see the bottom line as longer.
evidence.insight: Even after learning that seasonal rates differ, the guest will still feel that the original rate is the 'real' rate and the higher rate is an overcharge. This is a cognitive illusion that cannot be eliminated, only anticipated. The solution is not to convince the guest that the higher rate is fair (that fights the illusion) but to prevent the single-rate anchor from forming in the first place (that avoids the illusion).

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 83-106
evidence.quote: Nightly Rate Display: Large: '$300.98 /night'. Updates dynamically. Interactive Pricing: System recalculates when guest changes days selected, duration, move-in date.
evidence.insight: The listing page already recalculates price dynamically when the guest changes inputs. It has the infrastructure to show rate variation by date range. The missing piece is not technical capability but information architecture: the page shows a single output rate rather than a rate schedule that reveals seasonal variation.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: the rate for the guest's selected dates, shown as a range if it spans seasons ('$280-$301/night'). Secondary: a compact rate schedule showing which rate applies to which portion of their stay. Tertiary: an explanation of why rates differ (seasonal demand, host pricing decisions) available on demand.
elements.disclosure_pattern: At listing evaluation: rate range displayed whenever the selected duration spans a pricing boundary. At proposal creation: blended cost breakdown by rate period. At acceptance: one-line seasonal pricing acknowledgment in the confirmation summary. In the Stays Manager: rate label on each Payment Schedule row so the guest can trace which rate applies to each payment.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 2 rate figures visible at listing evaluation (low end and high end of the range). Maximum 3 rate periods in the proposal breakdown (most leases will span 1-2 seasons). The rate schedule is a compact 2-column table (period, rate), never exceeding 4 rows. No percentage-based explanations ('15% seasonal increase') -- only absolute dollar figures.
scan_order: Rate range: '$280-$301/night' as a single compound figure (System 1: 'This is roughly what it costs', under 2 seconds)
Rate period labels: 'Oct-Dec: $280' and 'Jan-Feb: $301' (System 2: 'When does each rate apply?', 2-4 seconds)
Total cost derived from blended rates (System 2: 'What's my actual total?', 4-6 seconds)
Explanation of seasonal logic (System 2: only if the guest wants to understand why, 6+ seconds, on demand)
exclude: A single nightly rate that hides seasonal variation. If the lease spans rate boundaries, the guest must see the range.
Seasonal pricing disclosed only in terms and conditions, FAQ, or fine print. The rate range must appear in the same visual context as the primary rate display.
Percentage-based seasonal adjustments ('rates increase 8% in winter'). Show absolute dollars per night.
Rate changes disclosed for the first time at the Date Change screen during active_lease. By then, the guest has anchored on the original rate and any increase feels like a penalty.

elements.title: Proposal Progress Pipeline: Show the Guest Where They Are, What Happens Next, and Who Acts
elements.problem: The guest's proposal journey is a multi-stage pipeline: Submit Proposal, Rental Application, Host Review, Finalize Documents, Lease Documents, Initial Payment. The current design shows this as a horizontal progress tracker with stages marked completed, current, or upcoming. But the pipeline hides the most anxiety-producing information: who must act next and how long it will take. After submitting a proposal, the guest enters a waiting state with no visibility into whether the host has seen the proposal, is reviewing it, or has forgotten about it. Kahneman's research on uncertainty and System 2 activation predicts that unresolved uncertainty forces continuous System 2 monitoring: the guest cannot stop thinking about the pending proposal because they have no information to resolve the ambiguity. This cognitive drain persists for the entire waiting period, competing with the guest's work responsibilities and reducing their engagement with the platform. The Nneka call illustrates the downstream consequence: Brad ends up texting Nneka directly because the platform provides no status visibility.
elements.solution: Transform the progress pipeline from a stage tracker into an action-assignment display. At every stage, the pipeline must answer three questions: (1) 'Where am I?' -- the current stage, highlighted. (2) 'What happens next?' -- a plain-language description of the next step. (3) 'Who needs to act?' -- explicitly: 'Waiting on host' or 'Your action needed' or 'Split Lease processing.' Add estimated timeframes to each waiting state: 'Hosts typically respond within 48 hours.' When the host counters, the pipeline updates to show the guest what changed and what they need to decide, with the counter-offer terms visible directly in the pipeline context, not on a separate page. The pattern is: resolve uncertainty at every moment, even if the resolution is 'nothing has changed yet -- expected response by [date].'

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 311-327
evidence.quote: Progress Tracker (Six Stages): Proposal Submitted (completed), Rental Application Submitted (completed), Review Host Modifications (current/action needed), Finalizing Documents (upcoming), Lease Documents (upcoming), Initial Payment (upcoming).
evidence.insight: The pipeline shows stage names and completion status but not who must act, what the expected duration is, or what happens if nothing happens. 'Review Host Modifications' tells the guest they need to act but does not surface the modifications inline -- the guest must scroll or navigate to find what changed.

evidence.quote: He was texting me and saying, Hey, you know, I can't make it for another day.
evidence.insight: Brad resorts to texting because the platform provides no status channel for his requests. If the proposal pipeline had shown 'Waiting on host -- sent 2 hours ago,' Brad would know his request was in progress. Instead, the opacity drives him off-platform.

evidence.quote: System 2 is activated when an event is detected that violates the model of the world that System 1 maintains.
evidence.insight: The guest's model after submitting a proposal is: 'I acted, now something should happen.' When nothing visibly happens (no status update, no timeframe, no assignment), System 2 activates to manage the uncertainty. This activation persists as low-grade cognitive drain until the uncertainty is resolved. Showing 'Waiting on host -- expected response by Friday' resolves the uncertainty and frees System 2.

evidence.source: kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Busy and Depleted System 2
evidence.quote: Activities that impose high demands on System 2 require self-control, and the exertion of self-control is depleting and unpleasant.
evidence.insight: Monitoring an uncertain outcome is a continuous System 2 demand. Every hour the guest spends wondering 'has the host seen my proposal?' is an hour of depletion that reduces their willingness to engage with the platform for any other purpose. Status resolution is not a convenience feature; it is a depletion prevention mechanism.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: current stage name + who must act next ('Waiting on host' or 'Your action needed'). Secondary: expected timeframe or deadline ('Hosts typically respond within 48 hours. Submitted 14 hours ago.'). Tertiary: the specific content of the current stage (counter-offer terms, document links, payment amount).
elements.disclosure_pattern: Immediate on page load: current stage and action assignment are visible without scrolling. On the same view: estimated time remaining or elapsed time since last action. On interaction (tap current stage): full details of what is required, including counter-offer terms shown inline. Never require navigation to a separate page to see what changed in a counter-offer.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 6 stages in the pipeline (current design is appropriate). Only the current stage shows detailed information; completed stages show a checkmark only, upcoming stages show names only. The action assignment ('Waiting on host') is 3 words maximum. The timeframe estimate is one line maximum.
scan_order: Current stage highlight: which stage is active (System 1: 'Where am I?', under 1 second)
Action assignment label: 'Waiting on host' or 'Your action needed' (System 1: 'Do I need to do anything right now?', 1-2 seconds)
Timeframe: 'Submitted 14 hours ago. Expected response within 48 hours.' (System 2: 'When should I check back?', 2-4 seconds)
Stage content: counter-offer details, document links, payment info (System 2: detailed engagement, 4+ seconds, only if action is needed)
exclude: Pipeline stages that show only names without action assignment. Every stage must indicate who acts.
Waiting states with no estimated timeframe. 'Processing' without a timeline is anxiety, not information.
Counter-offer terms displayed on a separate page from the pipeline. The delta (what changed and by how much) must be visible in the pipeline context.
Completed stages showing full detail. Completed stages need only a checkmark and the completion date -- the cognitive resources should focus on the current stage.

elements.title: Schedule-First Listing Cards: Lead with Pattern Fit, Not Property Features
elements.problem: The search results page shows listing cards with property photos, location, title, room configuration, host name, and two pricing displays ('Starting at $235/night' and '$442.26/night based on selected schedule'). This is a feature-first hierarchy designed for vacation booking. But the Split Lease guest's primary filter is schedule compatibility, not property features. Bryant describes the core matching challenge: 'Monday to Friday is a very popular usage pattern... so there can be some difficulties there in matching with your listing availability' (10:17-10:27). The guest who needs Monday-Thursday nights first needs to know: does this listing have those nights available? At what cost for my specific pattern? For how long? The photos, amenities, and room configuration are secondary to schedule fit. Kahneman's limited attention budget principle predicts that every listing card that leads with photos and features before confirming schedule fit wastes the guest's finite evaluation capacity on properties that may be incompatible.
elements.solution: Restructure listing cards to lead with schedule fit information: (1) First element: a compact schedule compatibility indicator showing which of the guest's selected days are available at this property. Visual: the S M T W T F S day buttons with available days highlighted and unavailable days crossed out or dimmed. (2) Second element: the calculated cost for the guest's specific schedule, shown as a monthly equivalent ('$1,850/month for your Mon-Thu pattern'). (3) Third element: property photo, name, and location. (4) Fourth element: room configuration and host info. The CTA changes from 'Submit Proposal' to 'View Listing' if the schedule fit is partial, and 'Submit Proposal' if the schedule fit is complete. This reorders the card to match the guest's decision tree: can I use this property on my days? Can I afford it on my schedule? Does it look right? Is the host trustworthy?

evidence.quote: Monday to Friday is a very popular usage pattern, which we see... so there can be some difficulties there in matching with your listing availability.
evidence.insight: Availability matching is the core challenge. A listing that looks perfect in every other dimension but does not have the guest's required days is a wasted evaluation. Leading with schedule fit eliminates this waste.

evidence.quote: Would you prefer me to come to you with a guest, even if it wouldn't work for your exact listing availability as it's displayed? -- No.
evidence.insight: Nneka will not accept guests whose schedules do not match her availability. This is a hard constraint, not a preference. If the host will reject mismatched guests, showing those listings to the guest wastes everyone's time. Schedule fit is a pass/fail gate that must be evaluated before any other property attribute.

evidence.quote: You dispose of a limited budget of attention that you can allocate to activities, and if you try to go beyond your budget, you will fail.
evidence.insight: Each listing card evaluated by the guest draws from the same finite attention budget. A card that leads with photos draws attention to visual evaluation before the guest knows if the schedule is compatible. When the guest discovers incompatibility after photo evaluation, the attention spent on photos is wasted and cannot be recovered. Leading with schedule fit preserves the attention budget for compatible listings.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 37-53
evidence.quote: Each card shows: Property photo carousel, Location, Property title, Type and capacity, Room configuration, Host name and verification badge, Two pricing displays: Starting rate: 'Starting at $235/night', Calculated rate: '$442.26/night' (based on selected schedule).
evidence.insight: The current card hierarchy mirrors Airbnb: photo first, location second, price third. But Split Lease's differentiation is schedule-based matching, not property-based browsing. The card hierarchy should reflect the platform's unique value proposition: schedule fit first, then price in the guest's format, then property details.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: schedule compatibility indicator (which of the guest's selected days are available). Secondary: monthly cost for the guest's specific pattern. Tertiary: property photo, name, and location. Quaternary: room configuration, host info, and verification badges.
elements.disclosure_pattern: On the listing card (search results): schedule fit indicator + monthly cost + small property photo. All visible without interaction. On card tap/click (listing detail page): full property information, larger photos, amenities, house rules, full pricing calculator. The card-level information answers 'Should I look closer?' The detail page answers 'Should I propose?'
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 4 data points per listing card: schedule fit visual, monthly cost, property photo thumbnail, location. Two pricing displays ('starting at' and 'calculated') collapse into one: the calculated monthly cost for the guest's selected pattern. If the schedule is incompatible, the card is visually muted or deprioritized rather than removed (preserving the guest's sense of selection breadth).
scan_order: Schedule fit indicator: day buttons showing compatibility (System 1: 'Does this work for my days?', under 2 seconds)
Monthly cost for selected pattern (System 1: 'Can I afford this?', 2-3 seconds)
Property photo and location (System 1: 'Does this look right and is it in the right area?', 3-5 seconds)
Host info and verification badge (System 2: 'Is this host trustworthy?', 5-7 seconds, only if prior checks pass)
exclude: Two separate pricing displays on the same card ('starting at' and 'calculated'). Show one price: the calculated monthly cost for the guest's selected schedule.
Property photo as the dominant card element when schedule compatibility is uncertain. Schedule fit must visually precede or equal photo prominence.
Listings that are completely schedule-incompatible displayed at the same prominence as compatible listings. Incompatible listings should be visually deprioritized.
'Submit Proposal' CTA on cards where the schedule is only partially compatible. Partial compatibility should prompt 'View Listing' to encourage evaluation before commitment.

elements.title: Batched Review Prompts at Natural Reflection Points, Not Per-Stay
elements.problem: The Stays Manager activates a 'Review' button after every completed stay. For a 13-week lease, this means 13 separate review prompts, each asking the guest to rate Cleanliness, Accuracy, and Communication, and optionally write a text review. Kahneman's ego depletion research shows that sequential self-control tasks drain from a shared pool: the first review is thoughtful, but by Week 5, the guest's System 2 has been depleted by four prior reviews plus their work responsibilities. The result is predictable: early reviews are completed, late reviews are skipped or perfunctory (5 stars, no text). The per-stay review model treats each week as equally important, but the guest's capacity for administrative tasks degrades over the lease duration. Layer 1 (works-006) identified the process pattern of batching; this element defines the information architecture for when and how review prompts appear.
elements.solution: Replace per-stay review prompts with batched review moments at three natural reflection points: (1) After the first payment cycle (Week 4): 'You have completed 4 stays. How has your experience been so far?' This captures first impressions while they are fresh. (2) At the lease midpoint: 'You are halfway through your lease. How is the space working for you?' This captures the settled-in experience. (3) After the final stay: 'Your lease at [property] has ended. How was the overall experience?' This captures the complete picture. Each review moment presents pre-filled context (the weeks covered, the property, the host) and asks for a single overall rating plus one text field. The three review moments replace 13 individual prompts, reducing total administrative burden from approximately 39 minutes to under 6 minutes while capturing higher-quality, more reflective feedback.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 453-459
evidence.quote: After each stay: 'Review' button becomes active. Guest rates property/host. Rates on: Cleanliness, accuracy, communication. Writes text review (optional).
evidence.insight: 13 review buttons over 13 weeks creates a review fatigue cascade. The guest sees a persistent 'Review' action on every completed row in the Stays Table, creating an accumulating to-do list that the Stays Manager displays as incomplete work every time the guest visits.

evidence.source: kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Busy and Depleted System 2
evidence.quote: An effort of will or self-control is tiring; if you have had to force yourself to do something, you are less willing or less able to exert self-control when the next challenge comes around.
evidence.insight: Each review is a self-control task: recall the specific week, evaluate three dimensions, compose text. The depletion from one review reduces the likelihood of completing the next. By Week 8, the accumulated depletion means the review button is visual noise, not a prompt to action.

evidence.quote: Hybrid workers... typically looking for really weeknights or weekdays each week.
evidence.insight: The target guest is a working professional whose cognitive budget for platform administration is minimal. Asking for 13 reviews over 13 weeks treats platform feedback as a primary activity. Batching to 3 reviews treats it as a secondary activity that respects the guest's primary commitment to their work.

evidence.quote: We normally avoid mental overload by dividing our tasks into multiple easy steps, committing intermediate results to long-term memory or to paper rather than to an easily overloaded working memory.
evidence.insight: Kahneman advocates dividing tasks into easy steps, but the current design over-divides: 13 micro-reviews that individually are easy but collectively are overwhelming. The batched approach consolidates into 3 meaningful reflection moments that are substantively richer and administratively lighter.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: one review prompt at a time, appearing as a highlighted card on the Stays Manager at the natural reflection point (Week 4, midpoint, final). Secondary: the weeks covered by this review, shown as pre-filled context so the guest does not need to recall specifics. Tertiary: an optional per-week rating for guests who want fine-grained feedback.
elements.disclosure_pattern: At Week 4, midpoint, and final stay: a review card appears in the hero position of the Stays Manager (above the stays summary). The card includes: the weeks covered, a single overall rating input, and one text field. On demand: a per-week breakdown option for guests who want to rate individual stays. Between review points: no review prompts. Completed stays show 'Reviewed' or 'Review pending at Week [N]' rather than individual 'Review' buttons.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 1 review prompt per page load. Each review moment requires 3 inputs: one overall rating (1-5), one optional text field, and one submit button. The 3-dimension rating (Cleanliness, Accuracy, Communication) is available as an optional expansion but not required. Total time per review: under 2 minutes.
scan_order: Review prompt card headline: 'How were your first 4 weeks?' (System 1: 'Oh, time to reflect', under 2 seconds)
Pre-filled context: dates covered, property name (System 1: recognition, 2-3 seconds)
Overall rating input: star or numeric (System 2: minimal evaluation, 3-5 seconds)
Text field: optional, with placeholder prompt (System 2: composition, 5-60 seconds, only if the guest chooses)
exclude: Per-stay 'Review' buttons on every completed row in the Stays Table. These create an accumulating to-do list that the guest ignores.
Review prompts that appear on every weekly visit. Reviews appear at 3 defined moments, not 13.
Mandatory text reviews. The text field is always optional. A rating-only review is complete.
Review prompts that block access to the Stays Manager. The review card is prominent but dismissible -- the guest can choose to review later without losing access to stay management.
